Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Production of aromatic commodity chemicals via the coumalic acid platform using the catalyzed Diels-Â­‐Alder reaction in a continuous flow reactor
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project is the accelerated utilization of crop materials for the manufacture of biobased aromatic chemicals such as terephthalic acid and benzoic acid, which currently have global market value of $60 billion and $200 million, respectfully. This project focusses on benzoic acid (applications ranging from food additives to plasticizers) as the first commercial target to gain a market foothold and develop this technology. This technology will provide a biobased source for benzoic acid, which is currently produced almost exclusively from the oxidation of petrochemical toluene. Situated in Iowa, the epicenter of biomass production in the United States, SusTerea Biorenewables LLC can impact the rural economy, expand the utilization of crop materials beyond ethanol into the production of biobased chemicals.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project is development of the biobased coumalic acid platform, for producing an array of industrially important aromatic molecules. The technological basis for the project began with the identification by researcehers at the NSF Engineering Research Center, Center for Biorenewable Chemicals (CBiRC) of a chemical catalysis pathway to transform an industrially optimized fermentation product (malic acid) into coumalic acid and the discovery that coumalic acid could be used to produce an array of aromatics such as benzoic acid, terephthalic acid, and dimethyl terephthalate. Thus, coumalic acid has the potential to become a platform chemical opportunity in the burgeoning biorenewable chemical industry. First, the reaction conditions including temperature, pressure and solvent using an industrially relevant bench scale continuous flow reactor will be optimized. Second, new catalysts to substitute noble metals will be explored for the key aromatization step. Third, this experimental data will be used to construct a preliminary process design and a techno- economic model towards developing a scalable production technology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this STTR Phase I project, research and development work was conducted to explore using coumalic acid or its methyl ester as a platform chemical for producing functionalized aromatics. The aromatization step towards producing a potential product target was improved by the identification of all intermediates in the reaction pathway using multidimensional spectroscopy. Several of these molecules were found to have antimicrobial activity that is comparable to an industry standard. In light of these discoveries, the company has begun to form contacts and promising business relationships with the personal care industry interested in testing products for applications and formulations. The chemical conversion steps were conducted on a bench-scale flow-reactor capable of producing grams of product per day. Kinetic parameters for each reaction in the conversion cascade were determined, permitting process modeling of the flow-reactor and techno-economic analysis related to scale-up configurations including capital and operational costs for pilot scale. In addition, the coumalic acid platform was extended and enhanced to enable a range of potential product targets. In short, all major milestones and technical targets were achieved, significantly enhancing the commercialization potential of the processes.

The overall purpose of the work was to develop a commercializable approach towards a valuable functionalized aromatic that would match with customer needs. Further market analysis and customer discovery interviews, led to considerable insights into customer prerequisites, where we honed-in on higher-value, lower-volume markets. The personal care marketplace expressing a keen interest in green substitutes and more specifically the preservatives and antimicrobials market was identified as being well aligned with this STTR. A business relationship has been built with an outside entify as a supplier of the key fermentation technology. Process improvements of the dimerization process resulted in improved conversion economics. SusTerea has built solid relationships with cosmetics, food and feed manufacturers interested in new preservatives. These findings generally provide insight into multiple societal benefits, such as creating manufacturing jobs in the US as well as developing scientific innovations of value to society. Domestic production will promote rural development as industrial fermentation facilities are typically located in agricultural lands, creating jobs across a whole value chain from farmers to customer brand names.  In addition, the scientific learnings derived from this work significantly advance our understanding and approaches for the application of biological and chemical engineering in an economical and scalable process, delivering significant potential benefit to all members of society.


Last Modified: 09/05/2017
Modified by: Robert L Johnson
